title: How to Dehumidify a Car to Prevent Mold & Mildew

steps.title: Vacuum up lots of water with a wet/dry vac.
steps.content: Vacuum up lots of water with a wet/dry vac. If your car is soaked or if there’s a lot of standing water, you’ll want to start by getting that out. Use a wet/dry vac to remove the excess water. Take off the top of the vacuum and remove the dry filter. Then plug in the vacuum and start sucking up the water! [1] X Expert Source Victor Belavus Air Conditioning Specialist Expert Interview. 6 May 2020. If you don’t have a wet/dry vac, you can rent one from a hardware retailer or an appliance rentals center.

steps.title: Remove floor mats and hang them in the sun.
steps.content: Remove floor mats and hang them in the sun. Take out all the carpets and put them in the sun to dry. Using the wet/dry vac, vacuum up any water that was hanging out under the mats. Leave the mats out overnight. Run the vacuum over them if they’re still damp in the morning.

steps.title: Use bath towels to absorb water on your seats.
steps.content: Use bath towels to absorb water on your seats. Put several thick towels on the upholstery. This should absorb most of the water. Check back in a few hours to switch out damp towels and replace them with new ones. Remove the towels before you go to bed.

steps.title: Leave the doors open and run fans overnight.
steps.content: Leave the doors open and run fans overnight. If you can, leave all the doors open for at least 8-12 hours. Aim several large standing fans at the interior of the car. Focus especially on the seats. Let the fans run on their highest setting for at least 8 hours, or preferably overnight. [2] X Expert Source Victor Belavus Air Conditioning Specialist Expert Interview. 6 May 2020.

steps.title: Use baking soda to absorb the remaining moisture.
steps.content: Use baking soda to absorb the remaining moisture. If you managed to dry your car out quickly, you shouldn’t get any mold growth or musty smells. Just in case, sprinkle some baking soda all over the seats and mats. Leave this on for 24 hours, and then vacuum it up with the wet/dry vac. Baking soda can be used on all types of car interiors, including leather.

steps.title: Park your car in a sunny spot.
steps.content: Park your car in a sunny spot. If you can, take advantage of the sun and outdoor air. This will help dry out any dampness that’s causing mildew to form in your car. You’ll also want to dry out your mats in the sun. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Wear a protective mask and gloves while cleaning.
steps.content: Wear a protective mask and gloves while cleaning. Since you’re dealing with mold, it’s a good idea to protect yourself. Wear a mask and latex gloves. After you’ve finished cleaning the car, thoroughly wash your hands and change your clothing. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Remove mats and check for dampness.
steps.content: Remove mats and check for dampness. Mildew often grows in storage areas or on the floors of your car. Check the spare tire compartment, then look under all the mats. Don’t forget the trunk. You should also see if your air conditioner is leaking by feeling for damp spots on the mat that sits underneath the filter. [5] X Research source Leave the mats out and put them in the sun to dry.

steps.title: Scrub off mold with a nylon brush.
steps.content: Scrub off mold with a nylon brush. Once you’ve found your mold spots, tackle them with a nylon brush. [6] X Research source You don’t need to use any soap or water, as this could actually make the mold problem worse. [7] X Research source Just scrub at the mold until it’s removed from all the surfaces in your car. Then vacuum up all the broken-down mold particles. If the mold has left stains, use a carpet and upholstery stain remover. Follow the instructions on the bottle. If you’re cleaning leather, you may want to use a soft-bristled brush to avoid scratching it.

steps.title: Spray the seats with white distilled vinegar.
steps.content: Spray the seats with white distilled vinegar. Fill a spray bottle with white distilled vinegar. Spray it on the seats and any affected mats or carpeting. This will kill the mold. Leave it on there to soak in for about 10 minutes. [8] X Expert Source Victor Belavus Air Conditioning Specialist Expert Interview. 6 May 2020. Vinegar can be used on leather and cloth interiors. If you’re concerned that it’ll damage your car, however, spot-test a small area of the interior by putting a little vinegar on it and letting it sit for 10 minutes.

steps.title: Vacuum the entire car with a wet/dry vac.
steps.content: Vacuum the entire car with a wet/dry vac. Go over the entire interior with the wet/dry vac. Vacuum up the vinegar and any remaining dampness. Pay special attention to the areas where you found mold. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Sprinkle an anti-mold solution on the surfaces of the car.
steps.content: Sprinkle an anti-mold solution on the surfaces of the car. Go to your local hardware store to find an anti-mold powder. Sprinkle it on the seats, carpeting, floors, and mats. This will kill off any remaining spores. Let it sit for about five minutes, then vacuum it up. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Sprinkle baking soda to sit overnight.
steps.content: Sprinkle baking soda to sit overnight. The baking soda will absorb the rest of the moisture. Allow it to sit on the surfaces of the car for about 12 hours or overnight. Then use the wet/dry vac to vacuum it up. Replace the mats and enjoy your mildew-free car! [11] X Research source

steps.title: Keep a container of baking soda in your car to absorb moisture.
steps.content: Keep a container of baking soda in your car to absorb moisture. Fill a small container with baking soda. Put it on one of the floors of your car to continuously absorb moisture. Check the container every few days and replace the baking soda when it gets damp. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Look for leaks throughout the car.
steps.content: Look for leaks throughout the car. Ask a buddy to sit inside your car while you spray it with a hose. They can see if any water leaks through windows, doors, sun and moon roofs, or even the floors. If you’ve got leaks, go to a repair shop to plug them up as soon as possible. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Remove wet items from your car right away.
steps.content: Remove wet items from your car right away. Leaving wet clothes, towels, or even a cup of water in your car could cause the air inside the car to become damp. This might lead to the growth of mold and the return of that dreaded musty smell! To keep your car dehumidified, remove sources of dampness when you leave the car. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Dry out damp spots as soon as you can.
steps.content: Dry out damp spots as soon as you can. If your car does get damp on the inside, dry it out quickly. Vacuum the carpets and leave the windows and doors open overnight. Sprinkle some baking soda. Addressing moisture quickly will keep you from having to do a deeper clean. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Clean your car
steps.content: Clean your car every two weeks. Remove all trash. Wipe down the hard surfaces of the interior. Vacuum the mats and seats. Use upholstery cleaner to address any stains or dirt on the seats, then re-vacuum them. [16] X Research source If your seats are leather, use saddle soap to clean them.
